Brain Death Policy

Brain Death Policy Guidelines

GENERAL INFORMATION

  • Brain death is the total & irreversible cessation of ALL brain function, including that of the cortex and brainstem. The determination of brain death is the legal responsibility of the attending physician.
  • The diagnosis of brain death is a clinical diagnosis based on the absence of neurologic function with a known irreversible cause of coma. Brain death testing should not be initiated immediately post cardiopulmonary arrest or acute brain injury. A wait period of 24-48 hrs prior to brain death testing is preferred.
  • At the discretion of the attending physician, apnea testing should be performed with each required neurological examination. If only one apnea test will be performed, it should occur with the second brain death exam.
    1. Patients between the ages of 31 days to 18 years, require 2 neurologic examinations with a required observation period (listed below) between them.
    2. Adults 18y and older require 1 neurologic examination with accompanying apnea test.
  • Ancillary Tests are only required when components of the neurologic examination or apnea tests cannot be completed. Ancillary studies are not a substitute for the neuro examination.
    1. Such as: (1) any component of clinical examination or apnea testing cannot be completed, (2) uncertainty exists concerning results of clinical examination or (3) if a medication effect may still exist
    2. Recommended ancillary studies include EEG and Cerebral Blood Flow (CBF).
  • If 2 examinations are required, 2 attending physicians will perform independent exams and document their assessments in the EMR (using Brain Death dot phrase).
    1. If patient is a potential organ donor, the transplant surgery attending should not participate in brain death examinations.
  • Time of Death is noted as time of the confirmatory brain death exam.
  • Notify Donor Alliance when brain death testing is being considered.
  • An experienced provider, such as the attending physician, is responsible for providing information and education to the family regarding implications of the brain death exam and timeline of subsequent events.

  • Interval shortened because ancillary study is consistent with brain death

Adults (18 years and older)

Exam may be performed 24 hours following cardiopulmonary resuscitation or other severe brain injury

  • None, only 1 examination required

PROCEDURE

  • Prior to the clinical examination for brain death, the patient must meet the following criteria:
  • Absence of a primary, possibly remediable, condition. An etiology of coma must be documented by physician.
  • Absence of hypothermia. Core temperature greater or equal to 35¬∞C.
  • Absence of hypotension.
  • Absence of drugs/toxins in sig. amts to interfere with the dx of brain death.
  • Absence of metabolic causes of coma.
  • Normocapnia (PCO2 45-55 mmHg) or at patients known baseline
  • Once the above criteria are met, the pt should be evaluated for:
  • No cranial nerve reflexes: pupillary (pupils should be 4mm or larger), corneal, cough, gag, oculovestibular (cold calorics), oculocephalic (absence of movement on Doll‚Äôs Eyes‚Äîdo not perform if in c-collar). (Refer to Neuro Exam for Brain Death below)
  • Flaccid tone in all extremities with no spontaneous posturing or movement.
  • No response to deep pain applied via supratrochlear nerve, sternal rub or pressure to nailbeds (spinal reflexes may persist with presence of brain death).
  • Absence of spontaneous respiratory effort on ventilator
  • Procedure for Apnea Testing Prior to initiation of apnea test:
  • Patient should be monitored via ECG and pulse oximetry.
  • Pre-oxygenate patient with 100% oxygen for 5 minutes.
  • Measure arterial PO2, PCO2, & pH immediately prior to initiation of apnea test.
  • Apnea Test Procedure To be performed once.
  • Disconnect patient from the ventilator. Connect endotracheal or tracheal tube to a pre-assembled oxygen t-piece or a Mapleson circuit with 8-10 liters per minute flow of oxygen.
  • Observe patient closely for chest or abdominal excursions. If respiratory efforts are present, the test is inconsistent with brain death. Discontinue test, obtain arterial blood gas, and resume mechanical ventilation.
  • Assess arterial PO2, PCO2, and pH after 5 minutes, continue apnea test while results are pending. It may be necessary to continue test until PCO2 increases above 60 mmHg, not to exceed 15 minutes total
  • If PCO2 increases above 60 mmHg (and 20 mmHg above baseline PCO2) and there is absence of respiratory effort, the apnea test is consistent with brain death. If not, the result is indeterminate.
  • Monitor patient closely to ensure absence of cardiac arrhythmias, hypotension, or oxygen desaturation (less than 80%). If any of these conditions are observed, discontinue test, obtain ABG, and resume mechanical ventilation.

Ancillary Studies (If performed): Only one ancillary study below is necessary

Electroencephalogram (EEG) using "brain death protocol" - documents electrocerebral silence

Cerebral Blood Flow (CBF) Study - documents no cerebral perfusion

Other Study: Please Specify

ICP management

Elevated ICP:

  • Typically defined as ICP greater than 20-25 for 10 minutes
  • Goal ICP is typically less than 20
  • Clinical signs often include: headache, vomiting, vision changes, change in mental status or depressed mental status, pupillary changes, and cushing's triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular breathing) as a late sign and suggest impending herniation
  • See Pupillometry for noninvasive ICP monitoring

Treatment:

  • For TBI, refer to TBI pathway (in Clinical Pathway chapter)
  • Early involvement of NSGY (NSGY typical aids in ICP management)
  • Optimize sedation and pain control
  • Temporary options (as bridge to more definitive treatments):
    • Hyperventilation PCO2 to 32-35 mmHg, HOB elevated to 30 degrees, head/neck midline (to optimize CSF drainage)
  • If ICP drainage device is present, unclamp, place at 15 mmHg and inform NSGY
  • Preferred 1st line medical therapy:
    • 3% (0.5 mEq/mL Na+) Hypertonic saline (HTS) bolus 5 mL/kg/dose via peripheral IV or central line
      • Bolus hypertonic saline (HTS) if sodium less than 165 mmol/L
  • 2nd line medical therapy:
    • Mannitol 0.5-1 g/kg/dose
      • If fluid overloaded or not responsive to HTS
      • Can bolus if osmolarity (Osm) less than 340 MOSM/kg.
      • Can Repeat after 15 minutes if ICP remains elevated
  • Refractory ICP options:
    • Neuromuscular blockade
    • Deep sedation:
      • Ketamine/midaz gtt
      • pentobarb coma
      • Can titrate to EEG activity and ICP level
    • Hypothermia to 32-34‚Å∞C
    • Neurosurgical interventions (decompressive craniotomy, etc)
  • Cerebral perfusion pressure is defined as the difference between the mean arterial pressure (MAP) and ICP (CPP = MAP ‚àí ICP).

Pupillometry

  • Pupillometer (NPI) is a non-invasive device that uses an infrared camera that integrates a calibrated light stimulation of fixed intensity and duration allowing for a rapid and precise measure (0.05 mm limit) of the pupil size and of a series of dynamic pupillary variables.
  • NPI ranges from 0-5 (0.1 decimal increments)
  • NPI represents a proprietary scalar index (pupil size, percentage pupillary constriction, latency, constriction velocity, and dilation velocity).
  • Pathological NPI values are defined as less than 3
    • Lower NPI values suggest higher ICP
    • Changes in NPI trends can represent ICP changes and may suggest need for imaging or intervention (osmotic therapy, etc)

Citation: Jahns FP, Miroz JP, Messerer M, Daniel RT, Taccone FS, Eckert P, Oddo M. Quantitative pupillometry for the monitoring of intracranial hypertension in patients with severe traumatic brain injury. Crit Care. 2019 May 2;23(1):155. doi: 10.1186/s13054-019-2436-3. PMID: 31046817; PMCID: PMC6498599.

Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE)

Eligibility Criteria for Therapeutic Hypothermia (cooling):

1. Gestational Age ‚â• 35 weeks AND

2. Infant less than 6 hours of age (The decision to start hypothermia after 6 hours will be at the discretion of the neonatology attending) AND

3. Clinical signs consistent with encephalopathy AND

4. Evidence of intrapartum hypoxia including one of the following:

  • Prolonged resuscitation: continued need for positive pressure ventilation; required at birth and continued for greater than or equal to 10 minutes.
  • Apgar score at 10 minutes ‚â§ to 5.
  • Blood gas [arterial cord gas, venous cord gas, or postnatal (within 60 min) arterial blood gas pH ‚â§ 7 and base deficit ‚â• 16 mmol/L].

* Note: aEEG may be additional tool to determine degree of encephalopathy.

* Attending physician may decide to initiate therapeutic hypothermia for infants with mild HIE based upon complete clinical picture.

  • For clinical or electrographic seizures, treat via the "neonatal seizures after acquired brain injury" clinical pathway (see Clinical Pathways chapter)
  • Prognostication is typically a combination of clinical course/exam, EEG and MRI brain neonatal encephalopathy (MRI brain Wo with spectroscopy) after rewarming

Post-Arrest

-Consider early CTH if asymmetric exam, etiology unclear, or deemed useful for early prognostication

-Consider CTA neck in cases of hanging

-cEEG for at least 24 hours (and then as clinically indicated)

-myoclonic status is a poor prognostic feature but we do typically treat with loads, +/- midazolam drip. We typically avoid pentobarbital drip for purposes of myoclonic status epilepticus.

-Neuroprotective measures

-Avoid hypotension

-Normoxia (SpO2 92%-95% or PaO2 60-300 mmHg)

-Normocarbia (pCO2 35-45 mmHg)

-Normonatremia (Na 135-145 mmol/L, unless ICP concerns)

-Normothermia (avoid fever for at least 48 hours: Targeted Temperature Management or CICU may consider cooling)

-Euglycemia (80-180 mg/dL)

-MRI brain Without contrast at 72 hours post-arrest

-See Brain Death Policy section if needed

-For young patient with unclear etiology of arrest (I.e. SIDS) or epilepsy w/concern for SUDEP, consider genetics consult for WGS/WES
